data.text: Contents
Introduction

In January 2015, Local Authority Children's Social Care around England updated their individual databases onto a national database called the NHS Spine. This database links a child's individual record created by the GP's details to any records held by Social Services. This link is created through the child's NHS number.

The concept behind this was to enable health care professionals around the country to have real time access to patient details and also be aware whether a child was known to Social Services, the reason for them being known and which Local Authority they are known to. The system is updated by Social Services regularly so that the information is current. This tool is especially helpful in areas around the country where families are more likely to move to different areas or seek medical attention for the child in an alternative area. NHS England (2017) highlights that by sharing data, health professionals are able to support early detection and intervention of children in unscheduled care settings.

As the information within the system is sensitive information about prospective patients, only those who have had the relevant training will be authorised to access the information. The system will also keep a log of who has accessed the information so that multiple health professionals are not consistently accessing the same information for the same patient. This will also assist the Trust to monitor access. It is the responsibility of the managers of services to ensure appropriate staff are trained and the process of how to access and document the information is followed.

Appendix  shows the process in which a child will go through when they are booked into an unscheduled setting using SCRa and the process staff follow in checking a child's status. There may some differences in the screen shots using the Lorenzo system.
This SOP is to support the use of CP-IS across the following sites and services with the Mid & South Essex NHS Foundation Trust.

CP-IS provides additional child protection information to staff, shares local authority information with the NHS and allows staff to deliver a higher level of child protection. Sharing information effectively across health and care settings is vital in protecting vulnerable children and young people and preventing further harm.
CP-IS focuses on three specific categories: Those subject to a child protection plan;
Those with ‘looked after child' status (children with full and interim care orders and voluntary care agreements);
Any pregnant woman whose unborn child has a pre-birth child protection plan.

CP-IS has been implemented in Emergency Departments, Paediatric Assessment Units and Maternity Services (Central Delivery Suite). If a child presents for unscheduled care / maternity care and CP-IS identifies that a child has an allocated
social worker, the social worker should be informed and if concerns are noted a safeguarding referral should be completed.
If CP-IS does not identify the above three categories, a full risk assessment is still required and actions to safeguard if concerns are identified.
Scope
The purpose of this document is to:

To outline the processes that need to be followed when a child is booked into an unscheduled care setting (each site will agree the services to be included within unscheduled care services for CP-IS).
To help staff to identify children who are known to Social Services and the details of the allocated Social Worker.
To reduce the amount of time spent on telephone calls to identify the Social Worker but also reduce the number of telephone calls to Social Workers for basic checks.
Definitions

table_items.text: Child Protection Information Sharing – access to a database links a child's individual record created by the GP's details to any records held by Social services. This link is created through the child's NHS number.
SCRa Summary Care Record application – used to view patients details and CP-IS alerts

data.text: Role & Responsibilities within the Trust
Operational Safeguarding Committees
To oversee all Operational safeguarding children activity including training compliance and adherence to policies.
MSE Group Adult and Child Safeguarding Committee

To oversee assurance to the Trust Board that policies, systems and procedures and in place, disseminated and adhered to, to safeguard children, young people and adults at risk. Provides assurance on the implementation, monitoring and updating of policies, systems, and procedures within the Trust for safeguarding children, young people, and adults at risk. Responding to changes in local and national guidance, legislation, and best practice.
Staff responsibilities

All staff should be aware and familiar with the MSE Safeguarding Children Policy and Procedures (site specific) and their roles and responsibilities to safeguard and promote the welfare of children and young people (Children Act, 1989, 2004, Working Together to Safeguarding Children and Young People, (2015), What to do if you are worried about a Child (2015) and NICE Guidance (2009) When to Suspect Child Maltreatment 2017).
All Staff are responsible for following the Trusts Information Sharing Policy and Record Keeping Policy, and the CP-IS information Sharing Agreement.
All staff will be responsible for ensuring they have appropriate Smartcard Access to SCR or Lorenzo (depending on what system is being used on each site).
All staff are responsible for ensuring they have been shown how to access the CP-IS system and are aware of this Standard Operating Procedure.
Site Information Governance Leads
To offer advice and monitor information sharing process and privacy impact of the use of CP-IS.
To provide assurance that correct information governance systems and processes related to CP-IS are being followed.
Reception Managers / Service Managers
Ensuring all staff have appropriate access to SCR / Lorenzo
Agree who will be providing local induction / training for all staff accessing the system (substantive and bank / agency staff).
Triage Nurse (ED) and / or Clinician
The Triage Nurse / Clinician is responsible for:

Responding to any information gained from the CP-IS and complete a referral / make contact with the allocated Social Worker / Children's Social Care, if there are any presenting safeguarding concerns. Just acknowledging the flag does not constitute a referral.

The Triage Nurse / Clinician is responsible for ensuring that all staff subsequently assessing, providing treatment (including transfer for in-patient care) or discharging the child/pregnant mother, are aware of the Child Care Alert (flag) and information obtained and document accordingly.
Safeguarding Teams
Safeguarding Teams will add any flags onto Trust internal systems (ie. Medway) and monitor (if flags are used on individual sites).
Will respond to any requests by the members of public to have an alert removed from their records (local systems) if through further enquiry, case is no longer open to Social Services.
Review information from services when a flag is noted on CP-IS and liaise with Local Authority as needed.
CPIS Process

table_items.text: All reception staff (or receiving staff member) should check the Summary Care Record Application (SCRa), using the patients NHS number (if known) to confirm whether there is a child care alert on the child or pregnant mother's record (Appendix 1). A CP-IS Alert tab will be displayed for any child that is on a relevant plan where details have been uploaded by a Local Authority. If the NHS number is not known then the child (or pregnant mother) should be searched for by using the details available. CP-IS must be checked when a woman presents for labour. If a woman attends for delivery that has not booked at the hospital this should trigger a safeguarding concern and safeguarding procedures must be followed (regardless of the outcome of the CP-IS check).
To identify children or pregnant mothers who are known to Social Services and provide the details of their Social Worker. To maintain compliance with existing national safeguarding practice.

If the child or pregnant mother is known to Social Services, details of the child protection plan or looked after child plan must be printed, attached securely to the client's records and handed to the clinician responsible for the child's treatment for consideration under Trust Safeguarding Process. Information must be visible and accessible by the clinician. *Once a child/family has their case closed by Social Services, a flag will still appear on the child's Summary Care record up to one year afterwards. On the CP-IS Alert tab it will state the end date of Social Services involvement. After the 1 year period the flag will be removed from the child's record. It is not the Trust's responsibility to remove this flag and it has no involvement in the upkeep of records. This is the responsibility of Social Services

By sharing data, health professionals are made aware of circumstances of children or pregnant mothers known to Social Services when presenting to unscheduled care settings to support staff in their safeguarding duties.
and if the family has any concerns about the information on the CP-IS information they must discuss this with Social Services. This is a read only service for the Trust.

No patient record found on Summary Care Record Application / Lorenzo or the child / pregnant mother is not a UK resident, staff will note ‘not found on SCRa / Lorenzo' at the time of registration. The staff member must then follow normal safeguarding process if a concern is noted.

This is to ensure staff still raise a safeguarding concern, if required, for a child that has not previously come to the attention of Social Services or for a child that does not already have a flag on CP-IS.
The member of staff accessing the CP-IS system should acknowledge if there is a flag for the child. This should be done by clicking on the flag icon.
This will make sure that the Local Authority responsible for the child will be alerted that the child is accessing our services.
Acknowledging the flag does not constitute a

To make sure safeguarding information is shared, risk assessed and Local Safeguarding Procedures are followed. If a concern is noted staff have a duty to consider other information available to them to assess the risk
safeguarding referral. The flag is to provide

safeguarding information that must be used and considered to safeguard the vulnerable child. Where health professionals are concerned about a child, local safeguarding procedures should be followed and a referral completed and sent to the relevant Social Services Team. System 1 should be considered if more information / intelligence is required to risk assess the situation if CP-IS has indicated a CPP (Child Protection Plan) and / or a LAC (Looked after Children Plan).

If no CP-IS flag on Summary Care Record application the staff member involved should still ask the child's parents / carer if the child is known to Social Service as they may have a child in need plan or active involvement with Children's Social Care.
Other child needs would be identified that may not necessarily have triggered a Child Protection Plan.
The staff member should enter information taken from CP-IS according to local systems in the child / maternal record; detailing nature of alert and name of Social Worker / Local Authority.

The staff member is responsible for updating the child's records with details of an alert if they are known to social services, this must give the reason i.e. Child Subject to a Plan, Looked After Child. Details need to include the
following: the Local Authority Children's Social Care the child is known to, the Social Worker allocated to the child and the contact number for the Local Authority.
The Child / Maternity Safeguarding Team must be made aware of any information gained so that a flag can be added to any internal patient care systems (as per local hospital process).
The Safeguarding Team will add internal system flag alerts in line with current trust protocol

It is the responsibility of staff to follow correct process and to ensure the correct child record is accessed. Any problems with access, including accessing an incorrect record should be reported to the appropriate safeguarding team for advice and an incident report considered.
To ensure there is a process to review and learn from any problems in accessioning CP-IS.

All staff must adhere to Local and National Documentation guidelines.
Escalation of concern

It is the responsibility of staff to follow correct process and to ensure the correct child record is accessed. Any problems with access, including accessing an incorrect record should be reported to the appropriate safeguarding team for advice and an incident report considered.
Training Requirements
All staff must have completed appropriate level of Child Safeguarding Training and have agreed access to the summary care record before being able to access the system.
8.1.1  Local training in the use of the Summary Care Record should be part of service induction.

data.text: Approval and Implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the MSE Safeguarding Committee which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local safeguarding guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document Control Team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the MSE Safeguarding Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

What are you proposing to change?
This is a review of an existing guideline that now reflects the new MSE Structure
Why are you making this change? (What will the change achieve?)
To ensure appropriate guidelines are in place before a review of CP-IS compliance is undertaken. To ensure the guidance is applicable to all appropriate services within the MSE Group.
Who benefits from this change and how?

Looked after children and children at risk – early identification by appropriate sharing of information. Staff – Access to information that will allow staff to understand potential risks for individuals within their care.
Is anyone likely to suffer any negative impact as a result of this change? If no, please record reasons here and sign and date this assessment. If yes, please complete a full EIA.
No – Further action will only be considered for individuals that are found to have a CP-IS alert. This action will be with multiagency partners to safeguarding and protect individuals at risk.
a) Will you be undertaking any consultation as part of this change?
This is part of a national safeguarding agenda. No further consultation at a local level. Yes
